0.title: Are you afraid you may have hit early menopause?
0.description: The menopause, sometimes referred to as the "change of  life", is the end of menstruation.  This is when a woman's  ovaries stop producing an egg every four weeks.
0.author: John Muchangi

so_far.title: Post abortion care: A newly-wed's experience
so_far.description:
A newly-married woman from Mombasa has explained how her joy  turned into heartbreak when doctors explained that her weeks-old  pregnancy would be terminated. 
Marion, who did not want her second name mentioned, experienced  all the initial signs of pregnancy, including missed periods,  cramping and changes on her breasts.
so_far.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

1.title: A teacher's long, desperate wait for final surgery
1.description:
For  Kenyans out of Nairobi, surgery can easily change life for good or  worse. 
One  primary school teacher in Embu feared she had cancer, but a growth on  her body was found to be benign.
1.author: BY ALEX NYAGA

2.title: Fresh details of Mugo's cancer testimony that moved First Ladies to tears
2.description:
She has shared her experience many times, but last week former Health minister Beth Mugo moved African first ladies to tears when she – for the first time – revealed how she desperately struggled to hide from the media the shocking news of her cancer diagnosis. 
Mugo, currently a nominated senator, also hid from public for months as she painfully absorbed the impact of the 2011 diagnosis.
2.author: BY John Muchangi

3.title: Four habits that expose you to NCDs like cancer
3.description:
AS First Lady Margaret Kenyatta hosts other African First Ladies and health ministers in Nairobi today for a cancer conference, it’s time to reflect how nutrition and changing lifestyle contribute to the current burden of non-communicable diseases. 
In Kenya, between 2000 and 2012, deaths from non-communicable diseases (NCDs) rose by 44 per cent while the rate was 26 per cent in the rest of East Africa.
3.author: By Faith Kariuki

4.title: Traditional 'surgeon' who treated Kenyatta marks 60 years of service
4.description:
As I drive to Nduuri Village in Runyenjes constituency, I take a winding murram road, that seems impassable during the rainy season.   
         At the foot of the imposing Kirimiri Hill forest is the residence of the man who famously cut the Uvula of  the first president of Kenya, the late Mzee Jomo Kenyatta.
4.author: BY MARTIN FUNDI

5.title: New Report: Kenya to gain immensely by investing in NTDs control
5.description:
The London Declaration names 10 neglected tropical diseases that should be eliminated by 2020
Kenya stands to gain major  health and economic benefits by combating neglected tropical  diseases, making it one of the best buys in development, a new report  suggests. 
 It  suggests that Kenya would create $2 billion in increased productivity  from 2015-2030  by achieving the WHO targets for elimination  of some  of these diseases by 2020.
5.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

6.title: Cuba stamps out mother-to-child HIV, Kenya struggles
6.description:
Cuba has successfully eliminated mother-to-child transmission of both HIV and syphilis, the World Health Organisation says. 
The head of the WHO, Dr Margaret Chan, called it one of the greatest public health achievements possible.
6.author: BY AGENCIES

7.title: Rich, malnourished: the new fate of Kenyan elite
7.description: When I first saw South African journalist’s 1993 photo of a vulture that was stalking a hungry child in Sudan during a drought, I was disturbed by the extreme case of malnutrition.  The child was wasted, helpless and seemed to be on the brink of death.
7.author: BY VALERIE KOGA

8.title: Is PCEA Kikuyu Hospital losing its shine?
8.description:
In the absence of government medical  facilities, the PCEA Kikuyu Hospital is the most ideal hospital for  residents of Kikuyu and Kabete in emergency cases especially at  night, because of its proximity, perceived personnel deployment and  availability of health care equipment. 
But through the years, the hospital  has been degraded to the extent where it can no longer boast of an  emergency unit.
8.author: BY NJONJO KIHURIA

9.title: Why patients should be assertive in demanding second opinion
9.description:
The healthcare system has had an exclusive grip on all patient care decisions for far too long at the expense of consumer’s rights. 
 Clinicians routinely communicate life changing diagnoses like cancer or diabetes with an emotionless finality.
9.author: By David Makumi

10.title: Pneumonia cases drop sharply after vaccination
10.description:
The number of  children under five admitted for pneumonia has dropped by a quarter  since the vaccine was introduced four years ago. 
  Kenya was the  first African country to introduce the PCV10 vaccine in 2011 and  there was no prior data on what impact the vaccine was expected to  have.
10.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

11.title: Counties unveil modern medical waste incinerators
11.description:
Two counties are constructing state-of-the-art incinerators to handle a growing amount of medical waste. 
 The Nakuru county government is building its first incinerator in  Mai Mahiu while Embu County Government has already unveiled its plant at the Embu Level Five Referral Hospital.
11.author: BY JOYCE KIMANI

12.title: ARVs should be given at diagnosis, trial reveals
12.description:
A landmark trial shows that people with HIV should be given antiretroviral drugs as soon as they are diagnosed to lower their chances of Aids and other serious illnesses. 
The results, if implemented in Kenya, would see thousands more people receive the drugs.
12.author: BY STAR REPORTER AND AGENCIES

13.title: Cancer deaths on the rise in  Kenya, new study shows
13.description:
A study has shown that cancer is still top among diseases that lead to deaths of thousands of Kenyans. 
The study, “The Global Burden of Cancer 2013,” shows that esophageal cancer is the leading cause of cancer deaths in men, and cervical cancer was the top cause of cancer death in women, a study has shown.
13.author: BY WILLIAM MWANGI AND AGENCIES

14.title: Aga Khan gets new blood separation machine
14.description: A local hospital has bought a new machine for extracting platelets from the blood of donors.  The Aga Khan University Hospital, Nairobi, will use a Trima Accel machine for the service.
14.author: BY STAR REPORTER

15.title: Secrecy fuels HIV infections in Kisumu teens
15.description:
For only Sh1,500, Maurine got infected with HIV but she did not know about it until much later when out of fun she decided to walk into a testing centre. 
"We were just walking by the market when together with my two friends we decided to enter a VCT for a test – I turned out positive but did not believe the results, says Maurine, 19, from Rabuor in Kisumu County.
15.author: BY JOHN MARK

16.title: New Plan To Save Antibiotics
16.description:
The World Health Organisation has endorsed a global a plan to curb antibiotic resistance across the world. 
 The just ended World Health Assembly agreed that countries should implement plans to stop the the overuse of existing antibiotics drugs to ensure they remain effective.
16.author: BY STAR REPORTER

17.title: Letter From Berlin Day 4 - Coming soon to a small village very far from you: Really cheap electricity
17.description: About eight years ago, I wrote an article about the marvels of the telecommunications revolution in Africa brought about by the mobile phone.  And within this analysis, I explained what I thought was the one drawback of this wonderful news.
17.author: WYCLIFFE MUGA

18.title: Letter From Berlin Day 1: The difficulties of writing about climate change
18.description: Most of the things which scare Kenyans usually end up on the front page of  every mainstream newspaper.  Whether it be yet another attack by the  Somalia-based al-Shabaab terrorist militia; or an outbreak of cholera in the  capital city Nairobi; or (late last year) the prospects of an Ebola outbreak,  as Kenyans based in the affected West African countries fled the dreaded epidemic and returned home.
18.author: BY WYCLIFFE MUGA

19.title: Letter from Berlin day 3 - The Frog in the bucket of hot water
19.description: Most readers will probably know that the earth is steadily getting warmer in  small incremental degrees, ie,  global warming.  They may also know that this warming  leads over time to climate change, which is likely to bring all kinds of environmental devastation to the planet.
19.author: BY WYCLIFFE MUGA

20.title: Attacks have left kenya in a mental health crisis
20.description: Sometimes statistics to do with health issues can easily overwhelm us.  All chronic diseases seem to be on the increase, demanding urgent intervention.
20.author: BY JULIA KAGUNDA

21.title: Cancer Survivors Journey To Promote Early Testing
21.description: Most forms of cancer can be cured if detected early.  But for many Kenyans, the disease is always diagnosed in the final stages when it is too late for doctors to save the patient.
21.author: BY GEORGE MUGO

22.title: Born to be a mortician: why I chose a despised career
22.description:
If he was to choose his career again, Subisiso Chebii (Siso) would still go for the same job. 
He works at the Chiromo funeral parlour as one of the funeral directors.
22.author: BY ENOS TECHE

23.title: Medic seeks nod for first head transplant
23.description:
An Italian doctor has vowed to confound his medical doubters by proving that he can conduct the world’s first head transplant - in less than an hour, and as early as next year. 
Surgeon Sergio Canavero, confirmed that he hopes to operate on his first patient, a Russian with a rare genetic muscle wasting disease, and said he will carry out the procedure in China if he is banned from doing so in the EU or former Soviet Union.
23.author: BY STAR REPORTER AND AGENCIES

24.title: Top health body to expand guidelines on abortion
24.description:
A new study showing that low-cadre birth attendants can effectively diagnose and treat incomplete abortion in developing countries is expected to form the basis of new international recommendations for the treatment of incomplete abortion. 
The study, published in the medical journal Lancet last month, is expected to have impact on Kenya, where birth attendants like nurses were in 2003 banned from attending trainings on abortion care.
24.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

25.title: Aga Khan starts new pain relief for cancer patients
25.description:
Cancer patients at the Aga Khan University Hospital will now undergo new procedures to relieve chronic pain where all other methods and drugs have failed.  
The hospital said the procedure, called neuromodulation, is performed on patients who have been suffering from persistent pain for at least two months with the underlying cause not having been found.
25.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

26.title: why Mps might hold the last card in TB control
26.description:
When it comes to combating health epidemics and strengthening health systems in a country, the role of our elected leaders should not be underestimated. 
  Think about it, what difference it would make if there was political will behind health initiatives.
26.author: BY DIANA WANGARI

27.title: Group wants the poor to manage funds
27.description:
Vulnerable groups should be allowed to decide how they should benefit from health and social protection funds released by the Treasury. 
Chairman of the Kenya Community Based Health Financing Association (KCBHFA) Lucas Wadenya says those groups should be trained to participate effectively in decision-making processes.
27.author: By IBRAHIM ORUKO

28.title: Post abortion care: A newly-wed's experience
28.description:
A newly-married woman from Mombasa has explained how her joy  turned into heartbreak when doctors explained that her weeks-old  pregnancy would be terminated. 
Marion, who did not want her second name mentioned, experienced  all the initial signs of pregnancy, including missed periods,  cramping and changes on her breasts.
28.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

29.title: WHO release guidelines to prevent food poisoning
29.description:
A week after more than 80 members of Strathmore University suffered food poisoning in Nairobi, the World Health Organisation has released guidelines for food safety. 
The victims admitted to hospital were among 300 others who ate the food during the university’s seniors’ dinner.
29.author: BY ALEX NYAGA

30.title: Kenya needs Sh20 billion for TB
30.description:
Kenya requires Sh20 billion to effectively fund tuberculosis programmes in the next four years, National TB and Leprosy Disease Programme (NTLD-P) has said. 
Head of the programme, Dr Enos Masini, said the country is experiencing a shortage of funds.
30.author: BY ERIC OLOO

31.title: Why MPs Should Pass Tobacco Regulations
31.description:
Joshua Kyallo, Director of Africa for Campaign For Tobacco-Free Kids, says a tobacco epidemic is looming.  He spoke to John Muchangi
Tell us about Campaign For Tobacco-Free Kids work in Africa
The Campaign For Tobacco Free Kids (CTFK) is based in Washington DC.
31.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

32.title: Firms make Sh650,000 for every tobacco death - Report
32.description: A cigarette smoker’s life might be worth just Sh650,000.   A new report claims this is the amount the tobacco  industry makes for each person who dies from smoking-related diseases.
32.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

33.title: The Lottery of Birth in Kenya
33.description:
The world's most disadvantaged children, including some in Kenya, are being left behind in global race to improve child survival. 
 
Despite historic global progress in reducing under-five child mortality rates over the past 15 years, new research conducted by Save the Children has found that large groups of children are still being left behind, simply because of where they live and the circumstances in which they are born.
33.author: BY TRACY MUTINDA

34.title: Foundation May Spread Training of Lung Doctors To Kenya
34.description:
Kenyan medics might soon benefit from a training programme to become qualified pulmonary specialists. 
The East African Training Initiative is currently run in Ethiopia by US-based World Lung Foundation (WLF) in partnership with Addis Ababa University and Tikur Anbessa (Black Lion) Hospital.
34.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

35.title: Billionaires start Sh364 million global fund to defend nations like Kenya against tobacco lawsuits
35.description:
Kenya can now access a Sh364 million ($4m) fund to defend itself against lawsuits from tobacco companies. 
The fund was announced on Wednesday by former New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg and Bill Gates at the World Conference on Tobacco or Health (WCTOH) in Abu Dhabi.
35.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

36.title: WHO calls tobacco firms 'cockroaches' after failed MPs retreat
36.description:
World Health Organisation (WHO) has ridiculed plans by cigarette manufacturers in Kenya to fly some local politicians to a beach resort for a “sensitisation retreat”. 
The cigarette makers are fighting stiff anti-smoking regulations that the ministry of health has proposed.
36.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

37.title: Meet traditional skull surgeons of Marakwet
37.description: Skull surgery is one of the most risky and complicated operations.  However, some unschooled Marakwet traditional healers are doing it with ease.
37.author: BY STEPHEN RUTTO

38.title: UN maternal health report praises Kenya
38.description:
Kenya is among countries recognised for innovations that have helped reduce maternal and child mortality. 
Safaricom’s Jamii Smart clinical alerts and the HELP SMS Platform have been praised for relaying timely information to expectant mothers and community health workers, potentially averting deaths and complications.
38.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

39.title: Rising cases of lung cancer should serve as a warning
39.description:
I  remember one time my grandmother paid us a visit in the city,  she made a remark "how the world has changed. "
 She was referring to a  group of ladies who as they chatted, standing outside the restaurant,  would pause every now and then to take a puff from the  cigarette clutched between their meticulously manicured nails.
39.author: BY DIANA WANGARI

40.title: Vaccine stops most cases of killer pneumonia-study
40.description:
Cases of pneumonia among children in Kilifi have reduced sharply after the introduction of a vaccine in 2011, latest results show. 
 The pneumococcal vaccine was introduced in Kenya in 2011 mostly to prevent pneumonia and meningitis.
40.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

41.title: Healthy villagers put on drugs to stop trachoma
41.description:
Thousands of people in the Rift Valley will be put on drugs to prevent trachoma, a dangerous bacterial infection of the eye that can cause complications including blindness. 
Some 218,000 people will receive antibiotics to prevent the spread of the disease while those infected will be treated, medics involved in the programme said.
41.author: BY EDWIN NYARANGI

42.title: You're killing people, tobacco firms told
42.description:
THE World Health Organisation has put cigarette makers on the spot for flouting anti-tobacco laws like the ban on advertising. 
Last week, health officials from Africa met in Nairobi to mark 10 years of the WHO’s framework convention on tobacco control (FCTC).
42.author: BY GILBERT KOECH

43.title: Why pneumonia still kills thousands of children
43.description:
If  you were asked what were the leading infectious disease killers of  children under the age of five, what would your answer be?
 Unless you are a health professional or keep abreast with health information  regarding that particular demographic, I am almost certain that in  the top three diseases that came across your mind, pneumonia wasn't  one of them.   
And  if I was to warrant a guess, your first response was probably tuberculosis.
43.author: BY DIANA WANGARI

44.title: Nairobi Hospital buys latest heart-lung machine
44.description: The Nairobi Hospital has commissioned a new Heart-Lung Machine, known as the Cardiopulmonary Bypass Machine (CBM). The hospital is the first in Kenya   to acquire the Sh30 million German equipment, which is the latest in its series, the   S5.
44.author: BY WILLIAM MWANGI

45.title: Disabled matungu family inspires village groups
45.description: A SLIP in 2004 was all it took to change Rose Chibwire’s life.  She lost her right leg and has been on crutches since.
45.author: BY SHABAN MAKOKHA

46.title: ‘All In’ global HIV campaign begins tomorrow
46.description:
Kenya will tomorrow launch a new campaign to fight rising HIV infections and deaths among adolescents. 
 The National Aids Control Council says adolescents (10-19 years old) have been left behind in the Aids response and have been over-looked in global, national and local programmes and budgets.
46.author: BY JOHN MUCHANGI

47.title: More volunteers benefit from mothers app
47.description:
Following the successful piloting of a Whatsapp-like platform for community health volunteers and expectant mothers in Kibera, the second phase has now been launched. 
The second phase, launched last week in Nairobi,brings together a larger number of health workers.
47.author: BY FRANK MUCHUGU

48.title: 'Slight' fall leaves man bedridden three years
48.description:
A fall on a slippery road at night has cost an internally displaced family (IDP) family dearly. 
Peter Muiruri was walking home from causal work when he slide and fell.
48.author: BY PETER MWANGI

49.title: Charity fights inflated vaccine prices
49.description:
An  international charity has demanded that two drug manufacturers reduce  prices of their vaccines. 
  Medecins  Sans Frontieres (MSF), which has regional offices in Nairobi, says  today vaccine prices are at least 68 times more expensive than they  were in 2001.
49.author: BY  JOHN MUCHANGI

50.title: County breaks old taboos to sort out toilet problem
50.description:
Kisii is probably the only county in Kenya with the guts to admit it is facing a common but rather embarrassing problem: the lack of proper toilets. 
With one of Kenya's fastest expanding towns and the country's highest rural population density, Kisii region has always had a sanitation problem, but past leaders covered their noses and ignored it.
50.author: BY BENSON NYAGESIBA

51.title: New branding move to weed out fake chemists
51.description:
Kenya Pharmaceutical Association is teaming up with Private Sector Innovation Programme for Health (PSP4H), a UK-funded research project, to brand pharmacies that are licensed to operate by the Pharmacy and Poisons Board. 
 Branded pharmacies will display a uniform logo that will direct customers to seek services from licensed chemists, where they will be given professional assistance on prescription medicines and other services.
51.author: BY MERCY GAKII
